overview_of_class: This course will examine the evolution of the human species and explore the nature of human biological variation in the modern world. Principles of evolutionary theory and genetics will first be presented to provide a framework for the study of human evolutionary biology. The fossil evidence for human evolution will then be considered using comparative data from nonhuman primate ecology to help reconstruct prehistoric lifeways. Finally, the influence of environmental stressors (e.g, climate, nutrition, and disease) on modern human biological variation will be discussed. Particular attention will be given to how human populations utilized biological and behavioral mechanisms to adapt to their environments throughout evolutionary history. Carries science credit.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. They will learn the evolutionary and genetic processes that led up to the appearance of Homo sapiens and contributed to the diversity of life as we know it.
2. They will have an understanding of the comparative primate and fossil evidence for human evolution
3. They will examine environmental factors influencing human variability
4. They will have an introductory understanding of the key methodological and theoretical issues in biological anthropology.
